## What is a Star?

A massive ball of hot gas undergoing nuclear fusion.

## Our Sun

|----------|-------|
| Type | G-type main sequence |

slides.title: Star Formation
slides.content:
# Star Formation üåü

## Birth from Nebulae

1. Giant molecular cloud
2. Gravity pulls gas together
3. Protostar forms
4. Core heats to 10 million K
5. Nuclear fusion begins

## Failed Stars

| Object | Mass | Fusion? |
|--------|------|--------|
| Planet | <13 Mj | No |
| Brown dwarf | 13-80 Mj | Deuterium only |
| Red dwarf | >80 Mj | Hydrogen |

## Spectral Classes

OBAFGKM - Hot to Cool

| Class | Temp | Color | Example |
|-------|------|-------|--------|
| O | >30,000 K | Blue | Rigel |
| G | 5,200-6,000 K | Yellow | Sun |
| M | <3,700 K | Red | Betelgeuse |

## Luminosity Classes

| Class | Type |
|-------|------|
| I | Supergiant |
| III | Giant |
| V | Main sequence |

Sun = G2V

slides.content:
# Low Mass Star Evolution üåü

Stars like our Sun (<8 solar masses)

## Stages

1. Main sequence (H fusion)
2. Red giant (He fusion)
3. Planetary nebula
4. White dwarf

## White Dwarf

| Property | Value |
|----------|-------|
| Mass | Up to 1.4 solar masses |

# Stellar Remnants üíÄ

## Neutron Stars
- 20 km diameter
- 1 teaspoon = billion tons
- Pulsars: rotating neutron stars

## Black Holes
- Nothing escapes, not even light
- Event horizon: point of no return
- Schwarzschild radius: rs = 2GM/c¬≤

slides.title: Binary Stars
slides.content:
# Binary Star Systems ‚≠ê‚≠ê

## Types

| Type | Detection |
|------|----------|
| Visual | See both |
| Spectroscopic | Doppler shifts |
| Eclipsing | Brightness dips |

## Importance
- Measure stellar masses
- Type Ia supernovae (standard candles)
- About 50% of stars are binary
